title: How to Make a 4 Strand Braided Bracelet

steps.title: Cut 4 equal strands of cord or yarn.
steps.content: Cut 4 equal strands of cord or yarn. Wrap a fabric measuring tape around your wrist and make a note of the measurement. Then, cut 4 strands of cord or yarn that are about 2 inches (5.1 cm) longer than that distance. This will account for weaving and tying off the ends of the bracelet.If you're braiding thin thread, you may want to use 2 or 3 strands for each main strand of the braid.

steps.title: Tie 1 end of the strands together and tape them to a flat work surface.
steps.content: Tie 1 end of the strands together and tape them to a flat work surface. Gather the 4 strands together into a knot about 1 inch (2.5 cm) from 1 end. Lay the strands flat on a table and put a piece of tape across the end to hold the yarn in place. Then, separate the strands so they fan away from each other. [1] X Research source If you don't want to tape the yarn, try pinning the strands of yarn in place. This would work best if you were working on a flat cork or bulletin board.

steps.title: Braid the outer strands towards the center.
steps.content: Braid the outer strands towards the center. Take the rightmost strand of yarn and bring it over the strand that's next to it. Pinch the 2 middle strands together and bring the leftmost strand of yarn over them. [2] X Research source Keep the tension tight as you braid so your bracelet doesn't unravel.

steps.title: Bring the right strand over 1 and lift the leftmost strand over 2 strands.
steps.content: Bring the right strand over 1 and lift the leftmost strand over 2 strands. Repeat what you just did while keeping the tension on the strands tight so the braids are visible. Move the rightmost strand over the strand that's next to it and then pinch the 2 middle strands together. Then, take the leftmost strand and bring it over them. [3] X Research source Try to remember that you're working over a single strand from the right and over a double strand when you braid from the left.

steps.title: Keep braiding the outermost strands until you reach the end of your yarn.
steps.content: Keep braiding the outermost strands until you reach the end of your yarn. You can stop braiding when you're about 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the bottom. Try to keep the tension the same as you work from the top of the yarn to the bottom. For example, don't start really tight and then become loose as you reach the end of the yarn or your bracelet will be uneven. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Tie the bottom end of the braid.
steps.content: Tie the bottom end of the braid. Once you're about 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the end of the yarn, stop braiding and pinch the strands of yarn together. Tie the yarn into a strong knot. Then, remove the tape from the top end of the braid. [5] X Research source Leave the excess yarn that's sticking out from the ends so you can tie the braid into a bracelet.

steps.title: Wrap the braid around your wrist and tie the ends together.
steps.content: Wrap the braid around your wrist and tie the ends together. Since it can be tricky to tie a knot using 1 hand, ask a friend to knot the ends together for you. If you have a long bracelet, you may be able to tie a knot at the ends before sliding it onto your wrist. [6] X Research source If you make an extra-large bracelet, you can wear it as an anklet.

steps.title: Cut 4 strands of cord, leather, or thick yarn into equal lengths.
steps.content: Cut 4 strands of cord, leather, or thick yarn into equal lengths. Wrap a flexible measuring tape around your wrist and add at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) to the measurement. Then, cut your firm material, such as cord or leather, into 4 equal pieces according to the new measurement. [7] X Research source Although you can use a thick yarn, your round bracelet won't be as sturdy as a bracelet made with leather or cord.

steps.title: Gather 1 end of the strands in a knot and tie it to your work surface.
steps.content: Gather 1 end of the strands in a knot and tie it to your work surface. Hold the 4 pieces near 1 end and tie a knot about 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the end. Then, lay the knot on the table and place a piece of tape over it so the knot doesn't slide around. Separate the 4 strands so they fan out and away from each other. [8] X Research source If you're using 2 colors, alternate the colors when you arrange the strands.

steps.title: Wrap the left strand around and through the 2 middle strands.
steps.content: Wrap the left strand around and through the 2 middle strands. Take the leftmost strand and bring it underneath the 2 middle strands. Take it up and then down between the 2 strands. [9] X Research source Tug on the strands as you work so the tension shapes the round braid.

steps.title: Wrap the right strand around and between the 2 middle strands.
steps.content: Wrap the right strand around and between the 2 middle strands. At this point, you'll have 4 strands in front of you, but you'll see a slight twist near the top of the middle 2. Take the rightmost strand and wrap it underneath these 2 middle strands. Bring it around and then down between them. [10] X Research source You may want to hold the 2 middle strands in place with your non-dominant hand and use your dominant hand to hold the working strand.

steps.title: Continue to braid with the leftmost and rightmost strands.
steps.content: Continue to braid with the leftmost and rightmost strands. To form the round braid, keep bringing an outer strand under and around the middle strands and tug tightly once you've wrapped it. Braid until you're about 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the bottom of the strands. [11] X Research source Remember to alternate braiding the leftmost and rightmost strands so your braid doesn't become lopsided.

steps.title: Make a knot when you reach the end and tie the bracelet around your wrist.
steps.content: Make a knot when you reach the end and tie the bracelet around your wrist. Make the knot at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) away from the bottom of the strands. Then, peel the braid off of the tape and wrap it around your wrist. Tie a knot using both ends of the braid so it doesn't slide off of your wrist. If you can't tie the bracelet yourself, ask a friend to help you or tie it before you slide it onto your wrist.
